text: Paris is filled with breathtaking landmarks, world-class museums, and charming streets
just waiting to be explored. But with so much to see and so much to do, planning the perfect
four-day itinerary can feel overwhelming. If you're like us, you don't want to miss out on the key
sites or waste time commuting and feeling rushed. Then we need a plan that balances must-see
attractions with the time to soak in the city's charm. So based on our personal experience from
the last 25 years visiting the city, in this video we'll show you our perfect Paris itinerary,
including a day trip to Versailles. Allez, on y va! Okay, let's start with day one. Chances are
you're feeling the effects of jet lag and you're probably tired after flying for eight to ten hours,
so we're going to take it easy today. If you arrived in Charles de Gaulle, we recommend booking
the fast-track meet and greet to escort you through customs and out to your driver. We tried it about
a month ago and it was very nice to be escorted right from outside the plane to our driver. So
let's drop off the luggage at your hotel and start exploring the city of lights. And it should be
about lunchtime by now, so let's go get something to eat. You're probably ready for some of those
dishes you've been dreaming about. Now most restaurants close at 2 30 and won't open again
before 7 p.m. and your best bet is to go to a service-continued restaurant. Let's head over
to the Pied de Couchon near Léal and have something delicious like their nice French onion soup or a
charcuterie platter. After lunch, we're pretty close to some of the most beautiful covered passages
in Paris, so let's start with the Passage du Grand Surf. Then we'll head over to the Vivienne and the
Passage de Panoramas and finish with the Passage Joffois. I'll put a link with the walking directions
in the description below. Now it's time to head back to your hotel to freshen up for the evening.
And for your first evening in Paris, we recommend booking a tour in a vintage du
Chaveau so you can see the whole city and get the lay of the land. And they will pick you up right
at your hotel and that's super convenient. We've done it a few times and it's a lot of fun. You get
to see all of the major monuments of Paris and you go through Montmartre. But best of all, you end the
ride at the Eiffel Tower with a glass of champagne to enjoy the twinkling lights. Now this has been a
long day and it's time to get some rest. Tomorrow will be a lot of fun but don't forget to set your
alarm clock. The jet lag in the morning may be rough for some. Good morning and welcome to day two.
Now if you're like me, this is when you'll feel the jet lag and won't want to get out of bed. Or
if you're like Colleen, you're just too excited to start exploring. In any case, let's start the day
with a delicious breakfast pastry like a pain au chocolat or an almond croissant and a strong
double espresso. And by the way, we call it an expresso in Paris. Espresso is what you have in
Italy. There are bakeries at almost every street corner in Paris so it shouldn't be hard to find
one nearby. But we've put together a list of our favorite bakeries around Paris so check out the
link in the description. Once you caffeinate it, let's head to the Trocadero. From there, you'll get
the best daylight reveal of the Eiffel Tower from this beautiful terrace. Now beware of scammers and
pickpockets here. There is not much to do here but you can get some amazing shots and selfies. Now
head to the Eiffel Tower by foot and the bridge between the Trocadero and the Eiffel Tower is now
close to traffic so that's another spot to get some great photography. If you want to climb the
Eiffel Tower, you'll need to have bought your ticket in advance and I'm going to put a link
to the official website in the description below. Now a couple of hours for the Iron Lady should be
sufficient. Once you're back on the ground, head to the iconic Alexander III Bridge and take it all
in. Built roughly around the same time as the Eiffel Tower, the views are breathtaking. From there,
either take a stroll behind the Petit Palais to see the bouquet of tulips or take a quick visit
to the Petit Palais which is a fine art museum and is free. Now let's head to the Place de la
Concorde to take a few pictures and walk through the Tuileries Gardens. The Tuileries Gardens are
nestled between the Le Louvre Museum and Place de la Concorde. It's a stunning 17th century park
designed by Lenot and it features manicured lawn, elegant fountains and sculptures. It's perfect for
a relaxing stroll. A favorite for locals and tourists, it offers a peaceful escape from
central Paris. Now it's time to grab some lunch and you'll have plenty of options around you.
You can grab a quick sandwich at Beau and me or sit at a nearby cafe to get some rest. In this area
we love Café de l'Orac or Le Petit Vendôme near Place Vendôme. After lunch, the Opéra Garnier is a
quick walk and that's our next visit. You don't need to buy your tickets in advance but I would
definitely visit this architecture masterpiece. The interior is simply gorgeous. The Opéra Garnier
is a masterpiece of Beaux-Arts architecture. It was built in 1875. It features a grand marble
staircase, gilded ceilings and Marc Chagall's stunning auditorium fresco. Known as the inspiration
for the Phantom of the Opera, it offers guided tours and world-class performances making it a
must-visit cultural gem. After the opera, you are next door to the famous Gallerie Lafayette and even
if you're not in the mood for shopping, access to the rooftop is free and the views are exceptional.
From there, depending on how tired your feats are, either take the metro line 12 to Montmartre or
hail a cab and head to the Abès Plaza in the heart of Montmartre. Here you'll find plenty of cafe and
ice cream shops and Le Mure des Jeu-Temps. Now beware of scammers and pickpockets in Montmartre.
We're always on guard and we make sure our pockets and bags are zipped. From here, let's go up to
You can go the long way without steps or the short way via the stairs. It's really up to you.
Place du Tertre is the plaza with all the painters and artists and a fun place to visit. Next,
head to the Sacré-Coeur and take in the view. If you have the energy, the views from the top of the
church are breathtaking. Now this has been a long day and it's time for dinner. Be careful, you have
a lot of tourist traps on the hill, especially around Place du Tertre and the Sacré-Coeur.
Our favorite restaurants here are Boitot Lettre, the Hauss Bistrot and the Sanglier Bleu. In any
case, you'll need a reservation for all three of those restaurants, so make sure you do that before
you leave in the morning. After dinner, I'd recommend you take a taxi or an Uber back to your
hotel. Your feet need a rest and tomorrow's another full day of sightseeing. By the way,
if you want a copy of I Itinerary, you can download it in a printable PDF format. I've put a link in
the description or you can use the QR code right here and it will be free until March 1st, so take
advantage of that. Now some of you may prefer to have someone help you create a customized and
personalized itinerary. If that's what you're looking for, I've put a link in the description
or you can scan this QR code to book a consultation with a professional itinerary builder. Good morning
and welcome to day three in Paris. After breakfast today, we're headed to the most visited museum in
the world, the Louvre. For the Louvre, I would highly recommend booking a tour guide. It's nine
miles of galleries with over 30,000 art pieces on display. We've been there many times and we still
get lost sometimes. It's a massive museum split into three giant buildings on multiple floors. A
guide will help make sure that you see what matters to you most and you should be able to do that in
just a couple of hours. We put a link in the description to some of our favorite guides and
if you want to do it on your own, you'll need to get your time stamp ticket way in advance. After
the visit to the Louvre, let's head over to the Palais Royale with the iconic striped columns.
It's right across the street from the Louvre and you don't need a tour guide or a ticket to get in.
It's free and it's another great place for taking pictures and selfies. Now let's grab a quick lunch
at Le Grand Colbert, which is right behind the Palais Royale and it's the one that was made famous
in the movie with Jack Nicholson, Something's Gotta Give. After lunch, we'll walk over to the
Eglise Saint-Eustache near Les Halles. This area can be a little bit sketchy but we've never had a
problem there. The Le Coute head statue is always a fun place to take photos. From here, let's head
to the Tour Saint-Jacques near Châtelet and if you have time to climb to the top of the tower,
that view is amazing. Just a block away from there is the Hotel de Ville and the Hotel de Ville
in Paris. It is the city's historic town hall and it serves as the official building for the
mayor of Paris. From here, we'll head down to Rue de Rosier. Rue de Rosier is in the heart of Paris's
historic Jewish quarter in Les Mareilles. It's lined with charming boutiques, bakeries, and street
food vendors and it blends old world charm with a vibrant modern atmosphere. Its cobblestone streets
and rich cultural history make it a must visit spot and from there you're just a few blocks away
from Place de Vosges. Now, Place de Vosges is the oldest planned square in Paris. It's a beautifully
symmetrical 16th century gem in Les Mareilles. Surrounded by red brick townhouses with elegant
arcades and it offers a peaceful escape in well-manicured lawns and shaded benches. This was
once the home to Victor Hugo and it is a perfect spot for strolling, picnicking, and soaking in the
Parisian charm. It's also home to the famous La Corrette tea salon if you're in the mood for a hot
chocolate which is far better than Angelina's in our humble opinion. Here you can visit Victor Hugo's
home, do some window shopping, or sit in the grass for a picnic and relax. This has been another long
day and we'll have a quick dinner before heading back to the hotel. We have tons of options all
around Place de Vosges and we chose to have our dinner at Chez Genou. Chez Genou is a lively
provincial bistro known for its southern French cuisine, warm ambiance, and an impressive pastis
selection. With its cozy decor and buzzing atmosphere, it's famous for dishes like ratatouille,
steak tartare, and a decadent mousse au chocolat served in a big terrine. And now it's time to
head back to the hotel to get some rest. Today after breakfast we'll take a day trip to the city
of Versailles to visit the castle. Visiting Versailles castle is an unforgettable experience,
offering a glimpse into France's royal history and extravagant architecture. It's just 40 minutes
from Paris. The Palace of Versailles is renowned for its hall of mirrors, the opulent royal
apartments, and the intricate gardens designed by Le Nôtre. Arrive early to avoid the long line,
but that's another attraction where we would recommend a guided tour for deeper insights.
The gardens, fountains, and sculptures are perfect for a leisurely stroll or a bike ride. Now don't
miss the Grand Trianon or Marie Antoinette's estates where the Queen sought refuge from the
court life. After visiting the castle, it's time to head back to Paris and our first stop will be
the Arc de Triomphe. And if you have the energy to climb the 284 steps to get to the top, the 360
degree view of Paris is spectacular. The Arc de Triomphe honors those who fought for France,
especially during the Napoleonic wars. The massive structure adorned with intricate carvings and
statues. Beneath it lies the tomb of the unknown soldier symbolizing national remembrance. Next
we'll walk down the famous Avenue des Champs-Elysées. The Champs-Elysées is Paris' most famous avenue,
stretching from the Arc de Triomphe all the way to Place de la Concorde. It's lined with luxury
boutiques, cafes, and theater. And it's a hub for shopping, dining, and culture. And it's also very
expensive. So check out the price before you sit down and order drinks. Now to wrap up your day,
I'd recommend having a dinner cruise on the St. River. The options range from luxury cruises with
live music to more casual bistro style boats. And our favorite one is Le Calif, which is docked across
from the Louvre. A dinner cruise on the St. River is one of the most romantic and unforgettable
experiences in Paris. As you glide past the iconic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower, Notre Dame,
the Louvre, and the Pont Alexandre III, you'll enjoy a gourmet multicourse meal with fine wine,
all while soaking in the illuminated cityscape. Most cruises last two to three hours, offering
panoramic glass windows or open air decks for the best views. Whether celebrating a special occasion
or simply indulging in Parisian elegance, a St. Dinner cruise combines fine dining,
stunning scenery, and magical ambience, making it a perfect night out in the city of light to wrap up
your four-day itinerary in Paris. In this video, we showed you the ultimate four-day itinerary to
visit Paris. And next, I would watch this video about the top 20 day trips you can take from Paris.
